security_audit.summary: This skill contains three Python scripts that query NCBI Gene databases via official APIs. Scripts read gene lists from files and write output results. All network requests go to legitimate NCBI endpoints (eutils.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov and api.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov). No malicious patterns detected. Standard CLI practices for API key handling present minor exposure risk.

low_findings.title: API key visible in process arguments
low_findings.description: The --api-key argument exposes API keys in command-line arguments which may be visible in process listings. Code at batch_gene_lookup.py:261 shows 'parser.add_argument("--api-key", help="NCBI API key")'. This is standard CLI practice but users should be aware that keys may be visible to other processes on shared systems.

content.value_statement: Search and retrieve gene information from NCBI Gene database. Get gene symbols, RefSeq sequences, GO annotations, chromosomal locations, and phenotype associations for research and analysis.
actual_capabilities: Search genes by symbol, name, or ID across species
Retrieve gene metadata including RefSeqs, GO annotations, and chromosome locations
Batch process multiple genes with rate limiting
Fetch data from NCBI E-utilities and Datasets API
Export results in JSON, XML, or text formats
Query by disease, pathway, or biological process
limitations: Requires internet connection to access NCBI APIs
Rate limited to 3-10 requests per second without or with API key
Does not perform sequence analysis or variant calling
Limited to publicly available NCBI Gene database

best_practices: Always specify organism when searching by gene symbol to avoid ambiguity between species
Use gene IDs instead of symbols for precise lookups when available
Include your NCBI API key to increase rate limits from 3 to 10 requests per second
Cache results locally to reduce redundant queries and comply with rate limits
anti_patterns: Searching without specifying organism can return wrong gene from different species
Making too many rapid requests without API key can result in rate limiting
Using gene symbols alone without validation can introduce errors from typos
Expecting real-time variant analysis instead of using appropriate variant databases

faq.question: What gene databases can this skill access?
faq.answer: This skill accesses NCBI Gene database via two official APIs: E-utilities and NCBI Datasets API. These provide comprehensive gene information for all organisms in NCBIs databases.

faq.question: How many genes can I query at once?
faq.answer: The batch lookup script can process hundreds of genes. E-utilities ESummary accepts up to 500 gene IDs per request. Rate limits apply: 3 requests per second without API key, 10 with key.

faq.question: Can I use this skill offline?
faq.answer: No. This skill requires internet access to query NCBI servers. You can cache results locally after retrieval for offline use.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. Data flows directly between your system and NCBIs servers. No third-party services are involved. Only gene queries are transmitted.

faq.question: Why am I getting rate limited errors?
faq.answer: NCBI limits requests to 3 per second without an API key. Get a free API key from NCBI account settings and use the --api-key parameter to increase limit to 10 requests per second.

faq.question: How does this compare to other gene databases?
faq.answer: NCBI Gene is the most comprehensive database for gene annotations. UCSC Genome Browser provides genomic coordinates. Ensembl offers similar data with different API. This skill focuses on NCBIs API for easy programmatic access.
